item.title: Deep Dive: Cloud Backup for Slow Connections, Part II
item.description: This is the second post in my deep dive series on cloud backup for network attached storage (NAS). In this article, I’ll walk through preparing the test machine and the tools I used to evaluate candidate backup clients If you’re not interested in kvm or shell scripts and just want the results, you might want to skip to the next part. However, if you’re new to setting up virtual machines and ZFS or are interested in doing similar testing, keep reading to see what I did.

item.title: Deep Dive: Cloud Backup for Slow Connections, Part I
item.description: For detailed steps, scripts, and results, you can follow along with the GitHub repo that accompanies this series of articles here: neapsix/cloudbackup-benchmarks. In case further proof were needed, last month’s story about the companies that lost irreplaceable data in a literal towering inferno proves again that everyone with important files needs offsite backups. I don’t mean to make fun of the hosting provider or the companies who got caught without backups in multiple locations (OK, maybe them, a little bit).
